body: Links in our documentation/code are often shortened to not include a URL scheme, but there are common hostnames that can be matched against to find URLs that should be linked.  One example is the `b/` prefix for issues: https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/blob/master/scripts/bootstrap/compile.sh#L398.  Obviously not all users will want to match `b/\d+` as a URL, but at least thousands of engineers would if they were using Alacritty.

Parsing arbitrary regexes would be far worse for performance than what we do right now, which is why this is not supported. It's also questionable how nested URLs would be parsed reliably in reverse without even further performance penalties.

I'm not sure if there's an acceptable compromise as a middle ground here. It seems like double-clicking with semantic expansion should already work pretty well. Alternatively in the future we plan to allow selection using the keyboard, that would likely make working with these 'URLs' easier too.

issue.title: Piping visible text to external programs
Configurable URL Formats
issue.body:
# Feature Request

After reading [this article](https://banga.github.io/blog/2020/03/02/little-known-features-of-iterm2.html), I was envious of the ability to configure different link formats, which is a feature of iTerm. I wonder if Alacritty could extend its ability to configure a url launcher to include other reference types, such as clicking on a git commit hash to open the commit in GitHub.

## Rough Configuration Proposal

Disclaimer: not particularly familiar with YAML, but this illustrates what I would like to see:

```yaml
launchers:
  url:
    regex: <some good url regex>
    modifiers: None
    launcher:
      program: xdg-open
      args: []
  hub:
    regex: [0-9a-f]{8,40}
    modifiers: None
    launcher:
      program: /usr/local/bin/hub
      args: ["browse", "-- commit/"]
      
```

issue.title: Add modal keyboard motion mode
issue.body:
This implements a basic mode for navigating inside of Alacritty's
history with keyboard bindings. They're bound by default to vi's motion
shortcuts but are fully customizable. Since this relies on key bindings
only single key bindings are currently supported (so no `ge`, or
repetition).

Other than navigating the history and moving the viewport, this mode
should enable making use of all available selection modes to copy
content to the clipboard and launch URLs below the cursor.

This also changes the rendering of the block cursor at the side of
selections, since previously it could be inverted to be completely
invisible. Since that would have caused some troubles with this keyboard
selection mode, the block cursor now is no longer inverted when it is at
the edges of a selection.

Fixes #262.

body: I would love to have this to open files from the terminal, similar to VScode. For example, if a test fails and shows a stack track, having the ability to click it and open with $EDITOR would be incredible.
I would also like to be able to make use of other URLs, such as gemini://, irc://, mailto:, file:, etc.

>I would also like to be able to make use of other URLs, such as gemini://, irc://, mailto:, file:, etc.

For the urls you've mentioned only `irc` is lacking. The currently supported urls as of the version `0.5.0` are `http, https, ftp, file, mailto, news, gemini, git, gopher, ssh`.
Hm, a whitelist doesn't seem great.

>Hm, a whitelist doesn't seem great.

Yeah, we want eventually move to a more general solution for matching random things in a terminal outside of urls. We already have some infrastructure internally due to recent regex buffer search, just need to wire urls detection into the same infra instead of using hand written automata.

Currently the plan for this issue from my side is to support arbitrary regexes and then do post processing for things like parenthesis. That's probably going to be slightly less efficient than the current parser, but with the correct post processing heuristics it will hopefully give equal matching results while allowing anything to be detected as a URL. But it should allow recognizing basically everything as "URLs" and would also make it possible to do a bunch more stuff than just URL opening with separate launchers for each regex.

It can't. We need to update things immediately. Updating URL highlights multiple frames late is not an option, that's slow.

> as I imagine most users code out of a single high level folder?

That would **really** surprise me. In fact I'm not aware of anyone that does so.

I also see absolutely no point in anything you're suggesting.
There's no need to "manage the fs tree". It seems like you're severely misunderstanding what this issue is about.

I think master has the first issue resolved.

issue.title: Allow regex based regions to be clickable links

repository.name: kitty
repository.description: If you live in the terminal, kitty is made for you! Cross-platform, fast, feature-rich, GPU based.

issue.body:
kitty allows clicking regions that look like URLs by manually looking for the pattern: `known-prefix://url-chars` within `mouse.c`.

I would like to see this feature expanded to accept any regex based pattern.

I have a script that pipes `git log` output to `fzf`.  Each line looks like:

```
2575f3d4 ch12345 Git comment starts here
```

I'd like to be able to click on `ch12345` to open it within a URL like: `https://app.clubhouse.io/story/12345`

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Re implement the URL detection feature to accept one or more regex patterns.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

#### Attempt 1

Make my script detect the `[cC][hH]([0-9]+)` pattern and emit OSC 8 hyperlinks within each line.

Though this works just fine with kitty alone, when the script pipes git output to `fzf --ansi`, the latter eats up all hyperlinks as the give option does not go beyond processing ansi escapes.

> Someone opened a similar bug on `fzf` more than 6 months ago; however, this issue has not been resolved to date.

#### Attempt 2
My next attempt was to add the following line to `kitty.conf`:

```
map kitty_mod+o pass_selection_to_program kitty-open-helper.sh
```

```bash
#!/bin/bash
if [[ "$1" =~ [cC][hH]([0-9]+) ]]; then
  xdg-open https://app.clubhouse.io/story/${BASH_REMATCH[1]}
else
  exec "$@"
fi
```

However, the UX is a bit awkward: rather than simply reaching for the text and clicking it, I have to first double-click to select it and then CTRL+SHIFT+O to open it.  (One more keyboard shortcut to remember.)

It would be nice if I could simply reach out and click the `ch12345` text without having to select it first.

#### Attempt 3

Implement the approach as described within the [Hints](https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/hints.html) section.

This would work, but is different than the mouse based solution I am trying to come up with.
